instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message:
board was liquid damaged. no green light when try i to power it on and Hissing/ticking noise can be heard by the lvds connector.
SMC was shorted to ground, so i removed and replaced the SMC. but Hissing/ticking noise is still there.

board now turn on and passed ASD. where is the noise could coming from in that area?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message: Backlight coil, remove backlight fuse and see if noise is gone. Then check all resistors/caps/<CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>. Only mess with this if it really is an issue, I would probably not bother if everything works.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message:
noise is still there after i removed the backlight fuse. noise is not coming from the backlight coil, i can hear the noise below the coil area. it is audible. 

<CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> area it is all good. i have no problem showing backlight and images on screen.

also i notice something strange. i have to replug magsafe connector multiple time in order to get a green light. it can charge and detect battery info on OSX fine. 
after i get green light, i can turn on and off and repeat no problem. how i check if i did a good job on SMC? this is actually my first time replacing a smc which seems to be 1st success otherwise...

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  =12.52V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>  = 3.52v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>  = 4.93v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.32v

3.52v on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> seems little high than usual.


[U]Resistance between pin 17/18 and 27/28 of the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>[/U]
4 ohms on pin 17/18
22 ohms on 27/28

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message: When you get no green light is PPBUS and 3V42 present? I doubt this will be SMC related.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message:
sorry it is actually very dim green light.

Yes...

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> =12.52V and 3V42 = show 3.52v


i replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> before because it had corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message:
The green light issue is probably the magsafe board, swap it with known good one.
Measure the voltage on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR> and 7086.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message:
already tried another magsafe board and still same.

[U]dim green light[/U]
16.05v on pin1 of <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR>
6.80v on pin1 of <RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR>

when power on with green light
6.3v on pin1 of <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR>
6.70v on pin1 of <RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message: Check resistance across <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR>, if it's good replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector

they are good.

i'll have to do it tomorrow. i need to get some sleep. thanks :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message: Before touching anything I want to know what voltage is on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR> when there is no green light. If it also 16V then there is an issue with the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> circuit most likely.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message:
dim green light.

15.92v on pin2 of <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR>
16.01v on pin1 of <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR>


with green light.

0.019v on pin2 of <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR>
6.3v on pin1 of <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR>


i think there is also noise coming from this area as well.
maybe i should ultrasonic this board..



thanks duke, i;ve catch you tomorrow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message: Yeah <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is not pulling down <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR>. This could have a bunch of reasons, a clean would be a good place to start.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message:
I have also seen a bad <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> cause high voltage on pp3v42. It also kept causing <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> to blow until I replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.

I would compare resistance to ground on pin 1 on <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR> to a known good to make sure it is not partially short, then check <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> and replace <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> again just for good measure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message:
ok, i've ultrasonic the board, still no good and noises are still there.

i've even replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. no affect.

<CHIP>U6990</CHIP> had been replaced before. maybe i had a bad one from donor board?

<RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> is fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message: Looks like just a bad fan to me. That noise is an inductor/coil. Usually when you put pressure on the noisy coil the pitch will change. See if you can locate the coil that is making the noise, there are only 3 big coils near the LCD connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message: noise is coming from multiple locating, near the lcd connector and near the usb ports.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message: Find the coil......go over them one by one and put some pressure on them with something sharp/hard, finger won't work.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message:
but fan is working on other machine perfectly.



edit. actually after replacing <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>. i dont have dim green light anymore. not sure if this is temporary or permanent fixed.

but now, sometime it get a green light and fan doesn't spin and no post.
and sometime green light, fan spin and post.

is it power problem or sensor problem,  maybe it want to post but something preventing the fan to spin?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message: If noise is not present in S5 state (with charger), pull out <TRANSISTOR>Q7931</TRANSISTOR> and listen if appears again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message: You powered it down from battery, this will not exclude <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> circuit, so I still don't know if the noise comes from there. Power down with AC connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector

just to confirmed.

plug magsafe only, (noise present) board then auto power on, then i press power off switch (noise still present)


plug battery only (noise present) then i press power off switch (quiet noise)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message: So it comes from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> circuit. Bad <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, resistors, caps, FETs, traces

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector

ok noise is gone :) after injecting voltage to the board.

it was L6995 lol.. i pretty sure replaced this couple of time.

now i get a steady 3.4v on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> instead 3.5v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Hissing/ticking noise by the lvds connector
threads.message:
[B]sometime[/B] charger doesnt go solid green and doesnt turn on what could cause this?

when no green light =

PP3V42 - 3.47V
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> - 3.46V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> =12.52V
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> - 3.48v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.32v


however turns on with battery all the time.


can a bad L6995 coil damage <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> or <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> even tho i replaced these 2 chips for 3 times already when trying to find the noise?
